Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploratory Study for a Complex Adaptive System Testbed

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this EArly-Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to conduct an exploratory study of a research platform capable of validating theories of system design. The research platform will eventually be a cyberphysical system testbed where nominal and faulty behavior of the hardware, software, and human control subsystems can be experimentally observed and compared to predicted behavior by different design analysis theories. This platform will enable the development of a scientific process for design theory validation, explore the nature of nominal and faulty emergent behavior, and expand research into fault detection and system health management. This project is developing the platform through design, construction, and use of a small-scale testbed incorporating an autonomous robot team, software, and human interface and control. This exploratory study will address the feasibility of a cyberphysical testbed, establish a baseline for design theory validation on an example analysis theory, and provide preliminary data necessary for developing a more complex testbed.

If successful, this research will establish a general process for system design theory validation through experimentation. Further, the small-scale research platform developed in this work will provide insight into testing and predicting emergent behavior in systems and be used as a validation and evaluation tool to support collaborative research in the systems design community. The validation metrics that will be developed in this work can be used to optimize tools and methods in ongoing research to address the complex nature of failure in cyberphysical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this work was to explore how to calculate the accuracy and validity of a predictive systems design theory using a robotics testbed as a case study. The motivation for this stems from how complex engineered systems are designed using methods and practices which are generally extensions of product design. Theories and tools to predict how well a system will perform under various conditions are introduced to help designers make decisions. However, we lack a fundamental scientific approach to evaluating these new theories. The reason for this is that the complex characteristics of an engineered system, such as unexpected emergent behavior, are ill-suited for traditional application of scientific experiments where the change in a single variable are investigated. Therefore, this work explored how to develop the experimental procedures that can be used to validate a predictive systems design methodology.

 

Specifically, we looked at how to validate a design methodology that predicted how complex failure scenarios would affect the functionality of a robotic systems. To do this we developed two separate physical experimental testbeds where we could compare the predicted findings of the design methodology with some experimental results. Some of the important observations are that the experimental validation method must be context-dependent and abstraction-dependent. That is, the specific objectives that a system is to perform must be considered with respect to the theoretic predictions of a design analysis method. Secondly, because analysis can be conducted with various detail level, the validation itself is also restricted by that same abstraction limitation.

 

This work provided a foundation for several research efforts and educational activities. As a result of this work, there are two testbed for validating predictive system design analysis methods. These can be used as benchmarking tools to compare and evaluate these methods. Further, the testbed itself is designed to be a platform to understand the effect of potential failures on real systems. This platform has been incorporated into undergraduate engineering courses in system design.
